Description: Egyptian terracotta figure factor wearing comedy mask. Hands clasped together over paunch. Mould-made and hollow, with vent at back. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant fine gold mica, quartz and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Probably locally produced at the Naukratis Terracottas workshop that dates 3rd to 2nd century BC. No exact parallels, but a similar example published by Fischer, (Fischer 1994, pl. 27, no. 321) is dated from the Classical to the beginning of the Hellenistic period. A similar example from Myrina is dated 2nd to 1st century BC (Mollard-Besques Myrina 1954, pl. 228a M843, Myr 341). Fischer, J. 1994. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Mollard-Besques, S. 1954. Catalogue raisonnédes figurines et reliefs en terre-cuite Grecs Étrusques et Romains I, Époques Préhellénique Géométrique, Archaïque et Classique. Paris, Musée National du Louvre.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.302) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 96, nos 325-326)
